Articles.Content: I thought that engine plume looked off...
I'm sitting here almost crying, I can't imagine how Elon is feeling ;(
I must have been close to stage MECO
Im watching the youtube live feed (which is silent of commentary), are you guys getting any more info on what your watching?
Didn't see much of an explosion... Looked more like a structural failure with liquid oxygen escaping.

And here I said to myself when I got the webcast running.. "Oh, man... something tells me this is going to explode today."

.. sorry everyone. Its my fault. But... damn.

F**k it blew up... they're still piecing thi sone together... Well as we say..

"You will not go to space today. "

Space_Coyote
And ULA jumps with joy. This is devestating!
It also makes you wonder how it will be possible maintain crew on ISS now.
CRAP. I was looking away when the 'non nominal condition' occured! What happened?! I hope they do a playback soon.

Was there a burst of RCS near the start of the gravity turn? Long before the rocket went boom.

Also does the cargo dragon abort?
How about dragon capsule?
Aren't all the resupply vessels except the HTV now grounded? Oh dear this is bad.
I think that was it going past mach 1, Frozen_Heart
They are saying that the vehicle provides a LOT of data which is transmitted during flight that they will be going through now...... and for a while I imagine.
End of stream
Space flight are full of failures. Let's hope that the reason for this will be found and problems will be solved. Still, I am sad.

I also noted what looked like RCS need the start of pitch, but didn't think a ton about it... Cargo's trashed man.

What does this mean for future ISS deliveries? Only Russia can take stuff up there now till SpaceX figures out what went wrong!
It would be good if the abort system was attached to test itself in real world conditions. I doubt it though.

Looks like Dragon "survived":

Maybe it can land on its parachutes?

I hope the Dragon capsule aborted and survived.

Probably not though.
there was no explosion so i guess it is a structural failure

Was there a burst of RCS near the start of the gravity turn? Long before the rocket went boom.

I saw that too, but wouldn't they have aborted if it was anomalous?
So it went past max dynamic pressure, was supersonic, and wasn't doing any separations. Purely wild speculation at this point but what would even cause it to fail at such a stage?
